content: The "Return to Prudent Banking Act of 2009" may be cited as the Glass-Steagall Revived Act. The "Return to Prudent Banking Act of 2009," also known as the Glass-Steagall Revived Act, reestablishes a wall between commercial banks and securities activities. It prohibits insured depository institutions from affiliating with investment banks or securities firms and restricts officers, directors, and employees of securities firms from serving on boards of depository institutions. The "Return to Prudent Banking Act of 2009" prohibits individuals from securities firms from serving on boards of depository institutions, with exceptions. The "Return to Prudent Banking Act of 2009" requires the termination of any affiliation between an insured depository institution and prohibited entities within 60 days of enactment, and existing affiliations must be terminated within 2 years.
